revision.comment: Created page with 'Dino Romano recently took me to task for linking to a modern Italian (in Italian) marinara sauce recipe that took liberties he was right to object to, saying: "Even Neapolitans, ...'
revision.text:
Dino Romano recently took me to task for linking to a modern Italian (in Italian) marinara sauce recipe that took liberties he was right to object to, saying: "Even Neapolitans, known for some departures when it comes to plain tomato sauce, wouldn't use parsley and oregano AND onion mixed with garlic in a sauce." Here is his marinara sauce recipe. Actually, two marinara sauces, one with whole tomatoes and the other with pureed tomatoes. Prep Time: 30 minutes Cook Time: 60 minutes Ingredients: Ten pounds of VERY ripe tomatoes Garlic Olive Oil Salt Sugar Black Pepper Fresh Basil Pecorino Romano Cheese, grated Pasta Preparation: Continuing with Dino's introduction, he says, "I've noticed over the past ten or fifteen years that the 'younger' generation of Italian food writers have begun to truly bastardize so much of traditional Italian cooking that it has come to look and sound like the convoluted workings seen on American television cooking programs. Now THAT is a shame.
"A very traditional recipe (prepared in the best kitchens, both North and South in Italy) for 'Marinara,' a word which is indeed derived from that fact that a sailor or Marinaro would easily cook this meatless dish on board ship, was prepared virtually daily at our farm in Lexington, MA when we were growing up. One version included the entire tomato the other pureed tomatoes with the seeds and skin removed. It was best when our eleven acres of trellis tomatoes were in season. We moved from Sicily to the U.S. in the early sixties and my father farmed until just a couple of years ago. My cousins are still farming the same land, which was recently pegged by an historian as having been farmed continuously since the early 1700's."
Whole Tomato Version:
The ingredients listed above. Chop the washed tomatoes into small cubes (to reduce the area and cooking time). Sautee ten or fifteen large garlic cloves in olive oil until they are dark golden. Add chopped tomatoes and bring to a boil, stirring constantly to avoid burning or sticking. Pour in an additional quarter cup of oil (or more according to taste). Add salt, a heavy dusting of black pepper and about three tablespoons of sugar (depending on the acidity of the tomato you can use less or no sugar). Lower heat to medium and cook uncovered, stirring regularly, until all fluid is thickened. THIS SHOULD NOT TAKE FOUR HOURS BUT MORE LIKE A HALF HOUR. Why people insist on torturing tomato sauce on a stove for half a day is beyond me --- we call it the "Nonna syndrome." Remove from heat and immediately add a large quantity of fresh chopped basil. Cook pasta extra al dente and drain. Add pasta back to pan and add five or six ladles of tomato sauce to the pasta and stir over a medium heat until sauce and pasta are thickened. Serve each plate with an additional ladle full of sauce on top and a drizzling of fresh cold olive oil and a heaping of Pecorino Romano.
Pureed Tomato Version: Same as above except that initially you cut tomatoes in half, put into a large pan and heat until softened, not necessarily boiling. Run all the heated tomatoes through a Foley Food Mill to remove skin and seeds. It is important to run the tomato skins back through the mill three or four times to get all the richness out of them. This is where the flavor is. This mixture may be utilized immediately to make the above Marinara or stored in the refrigerator to be used as needed to make a completed sauce of any type marinara or meat sauce.
It can also be jarred immediately and stored for over a year. It is important to put a large sprig of basil into the unadulterated puree before sealing.
O.K., hope I haven't offended anyone by putting my two cents worth in. Keep up the great work.
Regards, Dino Romano
When I asked Dino for permission to publish his recipes, he replied,
"Please feel free to publish my recipe for simple 'marinara.' You might want to add that there is a parallel, sister version to this recipe where the garlic is NOT browned but put in completely raw. The method with which one introduces garlic makes for completely different flavor in just about any dish. Another version of garlic introduction to this marinara is fresh, uncooked garlic introduced with the fresh basil at the end."
What more can I say, other than Grazie Dino! Actually, I can say something more: Dino has begun to work with The Pasta Channel, and presents a version of his Marinara Sauce beginning with canned tomatoes (preferably without citric acid added), which will be perfect when sun-ripened tomatoes are not available.

{{User-Generated Content in Education/Contents}} {{TOCright}} <!-- Don't touch this line or the tags above -->
==FreeReading.net==
FreeReading.net is an [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_software open source] reading intervention program for grades K-6. The program is primarily designed for grades K-3, and has hundreds of research-based activities, lessons and materials that are available at no cost. The research used in developing this program includes the [http://www.nationalreadingpanel.org/publications/summary.htm 2000 National Reading Panel research] concerning the five Big Ideas in Beginning Reading (Phonemic Awareness, Phonics, Vocabulary, Fluency, and Comprehension). <ref>Freereading.net (2009). Retrieved October 2, 2010 from http://freereading.net/index.php?title=About_FreeReading</ref> FreeReading is currently used by educators in all 50 states and in over 180 countries. <ref>FreeReading.net (2009). Retrieved from http://freereading.net/index.php?title=Integrated_Program:_Intervention_A_for_K-1_%28IPID:_101%29</ref> Freereading is a F/OSS (Free Reading Software Systems) program designed to improve literacy. It is a high-quality, open source, free reading program designed as an intervention program for K – 1 but can be used for students up to 6th grade.
==What does being "open source" mean?==
Open source refers to the source code as being made available to developers that would like to add/edit content. While the core information is locked, participants are encouraged to share lessons using the Five Big Ideas in Beginning Reading as their guideline.
FreeReading.net is available for use under the [http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ Creative Commons license Attribution-Share Alike 3.0],also known as the "Wiki License" which basically allows you to use content so long as you attribute the origianal content and allow others the use this information as well.
==Launched in 2007== FreeReading was launched in 2007 and is the “first free, open source curriculum product approved for use through a state-wide adoption.” <ref>Wirelessgeneration.com (2008). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.wirelessgeneration.com/pdf/press-releases/FreeReading_Florida_press_release_01.pdf</ref> During the 2008-2009 school year, all districts within Florida were using this intervention program for the first time. This has helped save valuable dollars that would have been spent on literacy products.
==Updates to FreeReading== In 2009 FreeReading began a partnership with the Scientific Learning Corporation with the goal of contributing free neuroscience materials and new lessons to FreeReading thus expanding its reach into other subject areas. <ref>scilearn.com (2009). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.scilearn.com/company/news/news-releases/20090402</ref>
==Florida State Board of Education Adopts FreeReading==
[[image:Child reading at Brookline Booksmith.jpg|thumb]]
In the spring of 2008 Florida became the third state to adopt FreeReading. Districts and schools in Florida are using FreeReading's Intervention A program as an approved intervention tool.<ref>FreeReading.net (2011). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.freereading.net/index.php?title=Frequently_Asked_Questions</ref> This was significant in the online reading movement because "Florida is one of the top five textbook markets in the USA, so the move could lead to development of other free materials that might someday challenge the dominance of big educational publishers." <ref>Usatoday.com (2008). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://usatoday.com/cleanprint/?1298906311664</ref> The CEO and Co-Founder of Wireless Generation Larry Berger, stated that "Florida's decision is a significant tipping point, validating the notion that educators will consider high quality open source instructional programs as a viable option to support classroom instruction." <ref>Wirelessgeneration.com (2008). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.wirelessgeneration.com/pdf/press-releases/FreeReading_Florida_press_release_01.pdf</ref> For a chart showing how FreeReading correlates to the Florida standards [http://www.freereading.net/images/a/af/FreeReading_FL_Correlations_for_2008-2009_School_Year.pdf click here.]
==What does the FreeReading program include?== The core content provides activities that are of high quality and research-based. The scope and sequence of the instruction is provided. The 40 week program is a stand alone program, or can be used in conjunction with existing programs. It is designed to be taught for 30 minutes per day, 5 days per week to a small group of one to six students. The first half of the program is targeted for kindergarten students. For first grade students work can start at week 21. However, individual abilities and needs will determine the best starting point. By using reading assessment tools, when available, the teacher can fine tune the best place to start.
Teachers may also use individual lessons to supplement curricula and, as needed, use the program for older students.
The program includes core activities, educator-contributed activities, teaching tips and resources for phonological awareness, phonics, comprehension, vocabulary, fluency and writing. <ref>FreeReading (2009). Retrieved October 2, 2010 from http://freereading.net/index.php?title=Find_Activities</ref> The site provides free, downloadable supplemental materials like flashcards, picture cards, phonics cards, word list generator, word family lists.
==Uses in the Classroom== This research-based program has utilized decades of reading research with the goal of helping every child become a reader. The activities are broken into ten categories.
# Phonological Awareness – The process of learning to blend and segment the sounds in spoken words. # Letter Sounds – The most common sounds for printed letters are presented. # Letter Writing – Students learn the commonly accepted way to write letters. # Sounding Out – Students learn how to produce and then blend the letter-sound patterns to read words. # Word-Form Recognition – Sight words are learned (words that are recognized without having to sound them out). # Irregular Words – High-frequency words such as “the” and “was” are taught. # Reading Connected Text – Students presented with their first stories. # Letter Combinations – The most common sounds for letter combinations are taught sh and oa) # Irregular Words II – More high-frequency irregular words are learned to be read by sight. # Advanced Phonics – Words with inflected endings, silent letter, and multiple syllables are taught.
==Scope and Sequence of Phonological Awareness <small>(First Five Days Of Lessons)</small> == Each lesson is a three-part lesson: Warm-up, Introduce, and Build Accuracy
+0: Counting words in a sentence Introduce onset-rime blending (Mico version) fish, fire, foot, lamb, lips, lock, meat, mix, moon, nail, nut, fox
+1: Blending syllables name game Onset-rime blending accuracy (Mico version) foot, lamp, lime, meat, mop, nose, nine, run, ring, sun, van, zoo
+2: Counting words in a sentence Onset-rime blending accuracy (Mico version)lock, mix, nest, nut, rat, saw, socks, six, bird, bear, tire, dice
+3: Blending syllables name game Onset-rime blending accuracy (Mico version) zack, vine, watch, wave, bag, bed, king, key, pig, hand, frog, star
+4: Counting words in a sentence Onset-rime blending accuracy (Mico version) witch, wing, vet, vase, box, can, coat, door, gate, horse, girl, snail, truck
+5: Segmenting syllables name game Introduce onset-rime segmenting (Mico version) fish, fire, foot, lamb, lips, lock, meat, mix, moon, nail, nut, fox [[Image:laughing.jpg|400px|thumb]] ==Program resources==
Available free of charge at the freereading.net website are a number of high-quality program resources including: *Picture cards: Various sets and sizes of free downloadable picture cards *Sound pronunciation guides: Recordings in MP3 format of the recommended way to segment words into onset-rimes and phonemes *Most common sounds: The most common sounds for letters and letter combinations *Letter cards: Various sets and sizes of free, downloadable letter cards for letters and letter combinations *Regular and irregular words: An explanation of regular and irregular words *Letter formation guide: A teacher's guide to the proper formation of upper- and lowercase letters *Sounding out word cards: Free, downloadable index-card sized copies of all the words used in sounding out activities *Irregular word cards: Index-card sized printable copies of all the irregular words used in the Irregular Words and Irregular Words II activities *Decodable passages: Short passages constructed only from words that have been taught in the program or that students can sound out *Word List Generator: A searchable database of 2000+ words that you can print as index cards and use in helping students to learn word recognition skills *Advanced phonics word cards: Index-card sized printable copies of double-letter words, silent-letter words, compound words, contractions, and -ed words *Word families (phonograms): A list of all word families taught and links to printable lists of words in each family <ref>Freereading (2009). Retrieved October 2, 2010 from http://freereading.net/index.php?title=Integrated_Program:_Intervention_A_for_K-1_%28IPID:_101%29</ref>
==Advantages of the Program== The open source model combined with a Web 2.0 platform gives FreeReading program users significant advantages over the traditional publishing model. "Instructional material can be regularly updated to reflect the collective wisdom of teachers and researchers, can be produced and distributed inexpensively, significantly reducing or, in the case of FreeReading.net, completely eliminating the prices that schools pay for such programs." <ref>Wirelessgeneration.com (2008). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.wirelessgeneration.com/pdf/press-releases/FreeReading_Florida_press_release_01.pdf</ref> Additionally, the program is continually field tested and is constantly updated. This allows for districts to better use the money saved from the cost of traditional textbooks which schools nationally tend to spend almost 7 to 8 billion dollars per year. <ref>Wirelessgeneration.com (2008). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.wirelessgeneration.com/pdf/press-releases/FreeReading_Florida_press_release_01.pdf</ref>
==Are There User Guides and/or Video Tutorials for FreeReading?== While a comprehensive user guide for FreeReading is not yet available, you can watch FreeReading video tutorials here: http://www.freereading.net/index.php?title=FreeReading_Videos
There are also several YouTube videos that may be of interest because they show several of the program's lessons in action, such as: [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C8SKysawMoU team word builder game] and [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Du22FOA5u54 counting words in a sentence] can be viewed on YouTube.
==What The Program Does NOT Cover== The FreeReading program does not include oral language, conceptual understanding, content knowledge, or affect and motivation to read.<ref>FreeReading (2009). Retrieved October 2, 2010 from http://freereading.net/index.php?title=Integrated_Program:_Intervention_A_for_K-1_%28IPID:_101%29</ref>
==Who Created FreeReading?== “FreeReading was originally created by a team of reading product developers at Wireless Generation with the help of teachers throughout the United States. A leader in educational assessment, reporting, and professional development, Wireless Generation offers commonly used early reading and math assessments on our mCLASS® platform, including TPRI®, DIBELS®, IDEL™, Reading 3D™, CIRCLE™, Math, the School Enhancement Engine™ (SEE), and Tejas LEE®." [[Image:teacher.jpg|left|thumb]] ==Who Can Use and/or Edit== Even though this program is open source, the core activities are research based and locked so that they may not be edited. Teachers are encouraged to contribute other content to the website. <ref>Free Reading.net (2009). Retrieved October 2, 2010 from http://freereading.net/index.php?title=Frequently_Asked_Questions#Can_I_contribute_content_to_FreeReading.3F</ref>
==Advisory Board== There is an advisory board; however, since FreeReading is an open-source program, it is always being refined, expanded, and improved by everyone. The Board's main job is to insure that the research and development of FreeReading continues. The board is currently made up of Catherine Snow from the Havard Graduate School of Education, Michael Kamil from Stanford University, Barbara Taylor from the University of Minnesota, Barbara Kapinus a Senior Policy Analyst for the National Education Association, and Fred Carrigg the Director of Humanities K-12 at Middletown Public School. <ref>FreeReading.net (2011). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.freereading.net/index.php?title=Frequently_Asked_Questions</ref>
==FreeReading and the Open Educational Movement== FreeReading is part of the Open Educational Movement that was started by Jimmy Wales of Wikipedia and Richard Baraniuk of Rice University. The goal of OEM is to "represent a natural and inevitable evolution of the educational publishing industry in a way that parallels the evolution of the software industry, the music industry, and the scholarly publishing industry and to provide children with learning materials tailored to their individual needs." <ref>Eschoolnews.com (2008). Retrieved February 28,2011 from http://www.eschoolnews.com/2008/01/24/florida-adopts-open-content-reading-platform/</ref>
==Free Reading’s Partners== Wireless Generation http://www.wirelessgeneration.com
Minnesota Center for Reading Research at the University of Minnesota http://cehd.umn.edu/reading/
Primary Concepts http://www.primaryconcepts.com === References === {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
S.B.~ formatting, research and information, images, references, postings, editing, corrections
Three small concerns: # There seems to be a formatting issue by your first image. There are two EDIT buttons that seem to have overlapping content. Not sure exactly how that should be fixed, but explore if you have time. # The reference links are different from the model shared at http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Talk:Assistive_Technology_in_Education. All of the pages in the wikibook should have a uniform reference format. You could also check the page after yours which uses this reference format. # Rather than copy the complete text of the Governor's announcement, it's customary to simply place a hot link (like you did) to avoid redundancy. You could quote a particularly compelling section or you could paraphrase the part that you think is most meaningful. --[[User:Sgarrigan|Sgarrigan]] ([[User talk:Sgarrigan|talk]]) 04:04, 8 March 2010 (UTC)
I will address these issues this evening. Thanks for your input! S.B.
I made the corrections that I could this evening. My format is a bit different with the retrieval date after the citation. It would not show up if I tried to type it in as instructed. Thanks for your help! Sharon
Looks good now --[[User:Sgarrigan|Sgarrigan]] ([[User talk:Sgarrigan|talk]]) 04:57, 9 March 2010 (UTC)
I will finish editing the citations today. Thanks
== Spring 2011 updates ==
In regards to my contributions to this page: I added the category of CK-12 Foundation and content. I also added several links in the further reading section. I also updated the chapters in the Physics Book section. Furthermore, I fine tuned some items...like adding the hotlink to the Powerpoint mentioned under the Flexbook making, adding to titles, etc.
I actually had forgotten to log in a few times and undid items and redid them under my username.
Nichole K.
For my part, I added the VA state standards for each chapter of the physics flexbook, added images for that section and for the founder of Ck-12, added hotlinks in the contributors section, and modified the flexbook description to include the benefits of a flexbook.
Tom S.
Nice job Tom and Nichole, your page looks great. And Nichole I can commiserate with you not remembering to click save - I did that myself a few times! Nice Job overall.[[User:Margaret.mourer|Margaret.mourer]] ([[User talk:Margaret.mourer|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Margaret.mourer|contribs]]) 02:09, 7 March 2011 (UTC)
[[User:L0u1ser1ce|L0u1ser1ce]] ([[User talk:L0u1ser1ce|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/L0u1ser1ce|contribs]]) 20:56, 6 March 2011 (UTC)Peer Review: Louise[[User:L0u1ser1ce|L0u1ser1ce]] ([[User talk:L0u1ser1ce|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/L0u1ser1ce|contribs]]) 20:56, 6 March 2011 (UTC) Nice work on all aspects. NPOV in the CK12 category and benefits of flexbooks. Images are nice - I looked at code for another image and found that adding |left or |right would wrap the text around the image.
This page looks very informative...great work! SLR
From Sue: Lots of nice work. I'm glad to see in your comments that you spent time cleaning up the page as well as adding your own content. Sometimes it is hard to find our own grammatical errors that others can see. Since this is a community project and resource, it is always useful to have the community help put our best collective face forward.

{{Recipesummary| |Category=Bread recipes |Difficulty=Medium |Rating=3 }}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
==Ingredients== * 750 g [[Cookbook:Spelt|spelt flour]] * 2 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 sachet (7 g) dried [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] * 2 ½ Tbsp (40 ml) [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 500 ml lukewarm water
==Procedure== # Mix the flour, salt, sugar and yeast. # To the dry ingredients add the oil and enough water to make a firm [[Cookbook:Dough|dough]]. # Knead the dough for about 10 minutes. # Place in a greased 1 kg [[Cookbook:Loaf Pan|loaf tin ]], cover and leave it in a warm place until double in size. # Uncover and bake in a preheated oven, at 200°C, for about 35 minutes.
==Tips and Variations== * It is cooked when it makes a hollow sound when tapped on the bottom. * If shaped into a round and placed on a greased baking tray, you can make a country style loaf.
[[Category:Bread recipes]] [[Category:Spelt recipes]] [[Category:Baking recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]]

page.title: Bicycles/Maintenance and Repair/Chains/Installing a new chain

revision.text:
{{bicycles}} ==Installing a new chain== In general a new chain comes with detailed mounting instructions. For Shimano 8 speed or more , chain can be shipped : # With a preinstalled pin , that can be used to close the chain # Without preinstalled pin, but with a special reinforced connecting pin
Important is for Shimano, and probably for many modern chains, to DO NOT reuse ordinary pins . It is explained here : [http://www.parktool.com/repair/readhowto.asp?id=25] On modern Shimano chains you should push the original rivet out entirely and replace it with a special replacement rivet, reinstalling the original pin is likely to cause the chain to break at that point.
It’s important to buy the right type of chain for your bike. If you ride a geared bike then a multi-speed chain that is compatible with your drive train is the correct choice. It’s also important to make sure your chain is compatible with the brand of components you are using.
{{BookCat}}

Ftiercel moved page [[Talk:Java Programming/Introduction]] to [[Talk:Java Programming/Preface]]: Introduction -> Preface
revision.text:
Great page, this provides a strong foundation for the rest of the book.

--[[User:Mattylaws|Mattylaws]] ([[User talk:Mattylaws|talk]]) 00:14, 8 March 2010 (UTC)

=Merge=

I've suggested merging the contents of this page (not the whole section though) with the introduction page because although it gives the impression the user is about to actually do something to get started, 86% is talking about Java (I'm so sad I actually worked it out), something that I think should be done in the introduction.

--[[User:Mattylaws|Mattylaws]] ([[User talk:Mattylaws|talk]]) 17:29, 7 March 2010 (UTC) = Citation needed= I removed the citation needed mark on "everyone has once used a computer to do something". Clearly this is a false statement if interpreted literally, however, I think the intention is clearly to make a generalisation for the purposes of easy reading style. A more formally correct statement wouldn't enhance the meaning here. Furthermore, there's no way a citation could possibly be provided for this sentence. Either change the sentence or leave it alone, a citation needed mark needlessly clutters it up. --[[User:Fishpi|Fishpi]] ([[User talk:Fishpi|talk]]) 12:08, 19 November 2010 (UTC) == Is this getting started? == Surely this chapter is a bit much for newbies starting out, is there a need to bombard them with things like Abstraction, Classes, Objects, OOP or "Understanding Systems". I wouldn't have thought they would have any meaning to anyone who is new to Java or OOP. Does anyone have any objections to making the "Hello World" exercise at the end the main content of this article and leaving the rest until later when the user has a better understanding of the basics of Java. --[[User:Mattylaws|Mattylaws]] ([[User talk:Mattylaws|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Mattylaws|contribs]]) 09:21, 10 August 2012 (UTC) For what it's worth, I found the introduction of abstraction at this point to be helpful. I'm beginning to learn Java from a background in non-OOP and reading several books on the issue. I interpreted the kind of "abstraction" that's being introduced here as the programming thought process, not the particular feature of declaring e.g. an abstract class, which is of course out of scope at this stage of the course. In other words, I don't think total newbies will be confused because they won't know there's anything to be confused about, and for those learning programming for the first time, especially OOP, having this mindset as you go in will be, I believe, of great benefit. [[Special:Contributions/108.241.0.167|108.241.0.167]] ([[User talk:108.241.0.167|discuss]]) 14:27, 14 November 2012 (UTC) == java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError == If you're getting this issue, try this. Be sure and add a . (period) in the classpath followed by a ; (simicolon) -OR- In addition to adding your jdk to your System Variables path and the lib to your classpath (JAVA_HOME/lib), run the FirstProgram as so: java -cp . FirstProgram Hopefully it will save you a couple of hours.

S.W. - You did a great job presenting the advantages and disadvantages. It is very informative.
J.F. - Great job of covering a large amount of issues within the topic succinctly! Also, I liked the fact that you included a lot of links so if the reader wanted to find more information on a particular topic it was very easy for them to begin.
K.D. - Your wikibook page looks great. I din't even know there was such a thing as wikijunior. My guess is that this will become quite popular as my daughter gets older.
'''Two concerns:''' # In order for the book to have a uniform reference format on each page, I requested that the reference format from our sample page be followed: http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Talk:Assistive_Technology_in_Education # Usually the first paragraph would be sort of an introduction rather than jumping into factual details right away. This is a minor point but would help a reader who is unfamiliar with Wikibooks. --[[User:Sgarrigan|Sgarrigan]] ([[User talk:Sgarrigan|talk]]) 04:43, 8 March 2010 (UTC)
R.Y. - I think we addressed your concerns, Dr. G. Kelly added an introduction and I fixed the references. Thanks!
Contributions:
K.E. located resources, linked articles, created and/or revised content for Wikibooks in Education, Wikijunior, Featured Books, and Other Wikibooks Features. My partner is the real hero, she figured out the formatting and I piggybacked from hers :)
R.Y. haha...I'm no hero! located resources; linked articles; located and inserted images; created and/or revised content for History, Policies, Featured Books, and Other Wikibooks Features
S.R.P. I added the cookbook section, which took me a little to figure out how to get all the links to work. I also added information to Wikijunior and Features about the availability of languages. I augmented advantages and disadvantages but had little to contribute to the history section.
=== Peer Comments: Andrea Ayers === Did you have any issues linking your references? That provided me a little struggle when completing my portion of our OER page. Once I got one down it was smooth sailing. It seems like your contributions cleaned up the page a bit and allowed for easier navigation between content sources. Nice work! March 3, 2011
'''Peer Comment - SK''' This is a great page. Easy to follow and nicely detailed. I'm sure it's difficult to find many outside references since Wikibooks hasn't taken off the way Wikipedia has. Good edits and nice presentation.
=== Peer Comment: Courtney === Very nicely done! Very informative and well-organized!
=== Peer Comment: Teresa === Well Done! Very informative from all points of view, educationally and personally. The page flows nicely, giving the basic overview of wikibooks, then leading into specific types and uses.

==Radiation Oncology== TarHeelRadOnc, thank you for your contributions to the [[Radiation Oncology]] wiki! — [[User:Brim|Brim]] ([[User talk:Brim|talk]]) 22:49, 7 March 2010 (UTC) <!--btw, GTHC GTH!-->

revision.text:
Hi. Dr. G,
In regards to my contribution to our wikibook page entry:
JR I helped create Definition of User Generated Content, Forecast of User Generated Content USA, Exemplars of Web-Based and User Generated Content, co-authored links/references
Comment on two colleagues wikibook pages:
JR YouTube - provided a very interesting historical perspective in how Teacher Tube was created. Informative links.
JR CK Flexbooks - great insight about how both Florida and California embraced the concept of flexbooks for two very different reasons.

(short for ''ke fìfya srak?'') :{{NaviSE|adj|kelfpomtokx|ipa=kɛl.ˈfpom.tokʼ|src=.}} unhealthy (''lefpomtokx'' healthy) :{{NaviSE|adj|keltsun|sn=kelcun|ipa=kɛl.ˈtsun|src=.}} impossible (''letsunslu'' possible) :{{NaviSE|adj|kerusey|ipa=ˈkɛ.ɾu.sɛi̯|src=.}} dead (''rusey'' alive) :{{NaviSE|adj|keteng|sn=keteg|ipa=ˈkɛ.tɛŋ|src=.}} different (''teng'' same) ::{{NaviSE|n|tìketeng|sìketeng|sn=tìketeg|ipa=tɪ.ˈkɛ.tɛŋ|src=.}} difference :{{NaviSE|adj|keyawr|ipa=kɛ.ˈjau̯ɾ|src=.}} wrong, incorrect :{{NaviSE|n|keye'ung|sn=keye'ug|ipa=kɛ.ˈjɛ.ʔuŋ|src=.}} insanity ::{{NaviSE|adj|lekye'ung||lekye'ung|sn=lekye'ug|ipa=lɛk.ˈjɛ.ʔuŋ|src=.}} insane, crazy :{{NaviSE|adj|kxuke|ipa=ˈkʼu.kɛ|src=.}} safe, harmless :{{NaviSE|adp|luke|-X-|ipa=ˈlu.kɛ|src=.}} without (''lu'' be with)

(= ''pehem'') ::{{NaviSE|phrase|Kempe si nga?|ipa=ˈkɛm.pɛ si ˈŋa}} What are you doing? :{{NaviSE|pn|fìkem|ipa=fɪ.ˈkɛm|src=.}} this (action) :{{NaviSE|adv|pehem|ipa=pɛ.ˈhɛm|src=.}} what? (which action?) (= ''kempe'') :{{NaviSE|pn|tsakem|sn=cakem|tsayhem, tsahem|ipa=ˈtsa.kɛm, tsa.ˈkɛm|src=.}} that (action)<!--plural from Good Morning America prep-->

'''fìay'''- or '''fay'''- :{{NaviSE|phrase|fìskxawng|ipa=fɪ.ˈskʼau̯ŋ|src=?}} "this moron" :{{NaviSE|pn|fì'u|ipa=fɪ.ˈʔu|src=.}} this (thing) ::{{NaviSE|conj|furia|ipa=ˈfu.ɾi.a|src=.}} (as for) that; short for '''fì'uri a''' {{IPA|/fɪ.ˈʔu.ɾi.a/}} ::{{NaviSE|conj|futa|ipa=ˈfu.ta|src=.}} (think) that; short for '''fì'ut a''' {{IPA|/fɪ.ˈʔu.ta/}} ::{{NaviSE|conj|fwa|ipa=ˈfwa|src=.}} that; short for '''fì'u a''' {{IPA|/fɪ.ˈʔu.a/}} ::{{NaviSE|adj|nafì'u|ipa=na.ˈfɪ.ʔu|src=FE}} such, such a :::{{NaviSE|phrase|krro len ayhem anafì'u|ipa=ˈkr̩.o ˈlɛn ai̯.ˈhɛm a.na.ˈfɪ.ʔu|src=FE}} sometimes such things happen :{{NaviSE|pref|fìfne|X-|ipa=fɪ.fnɛ|src=.}} such a, this kind of :{{NaviSE|pn|fìfnel|fayfnel|ipa=fɪ.ˈfnɛl}} such a, this kind of (with genitive) ::{{NaviSE|phrase|fìfnel syulangä, fìfnesyulang}} "such a flower, this kind of flower" :{{NaviSE|adv|fìfya|ipa=fɪ.ˈfja|src=.}} this way, like this, thus :{{NaviSE|adv|fìkem|ipa=fɪ.ˈkɛm|src=.}} this (action) :{{NaviSE|pn|fìpo|ipa=ˈfɪ.po|src=.}} this one (person or thing) :{{NaviSE|adv|fìtrr|ipa=fɪ.ˈtr̩|src=.}} today :{{NaviSE|adv|fìtsenge, fìtseng|sn=fìcege, fìceg|ipa=fɪ.ˈtsɛ.ŋɛ, fɪ.ˈtsɛŋ|src=.}} here, this place :{{NaviSE|adv|fìtxan|ipa=fɪ.ˈtʼan|src=.}} so, so much, to such an extent (''txan'' much) :{{NaviSE|adv|fìtxon|ipa=fɪ.ˈtʼon|src=.}} tonight (''txon'' night)

==V==
{{NaviHW|n|Va'ru|ipa=ˈvaʔ.ɾu|src=FE}} :(male name)
{{NaviHW|adp|vay|-X-|ipa=vai̯|src=.}} :up to (a point in space, a point in time, or a number) :{{NaviSE|phrase|vay set|ipa=vai̯.ˈsɛt|src=FE}} up to now, still, (with a negative verb) not yet :{{NaviSE|conj|vaykrr|ipa=vai̯.ˈkr̩|src=.}} until
{{NaviHW|adj|vawm|ipa=ˈvau̯m|src=.}} :dark :{{NaviSE|n|tìvawm|ipa=tɪ.ˈvau̯m|src=.}} darkness
{{NaviHW|adj|vä'|ipa=ˈvæʔ|src=.}} :yucky, unpleasant to the senses (ugly of objects or sounds, foul of taste or smell, etc.) :{{NaviSE|n|värumut|ipa=ˈvæ.ɾu.mut|src=FE}} vein pod plant (''rumut'' ball tree)
{{NaviHW|?|väf...}} :? :{{NaviSE|n|väfewll|ipa=ˈvæ.fɛ.wl̩|src=FE}} centipede plant ('''ewll'' plant)
{{NaviHW|suff|ve|-X|ipa=vɛ|src=.}} :(suffix for ordinal numbers) :{{NaviSE|adj|muve|ipa=ˈmu.vɛ|src=.}} second
{{NaviHW|n|venu||mevenu|ipa=ˈvɛ.nu|src=.}} :foot :{{NaviSE|n|venzek|ipa=ˈvɛn.zɛk|src=.}} toe (''zekwä'' finger)
{{NaviHW|n|vey|ipa=ˈvɛi̯|src=.}} :food of animal origin; flesh
{{NaviHW|suff|vi|-X|ipa=vi|src=FE}} :(suffix for the product / spawn of something larger) :{{NaviSE|n|'evi|evi|ipa=ˈʔɛ.vi|src=.}} kid (perhaps the source of the suffix) :{{NaviSE|n|lì'fyavi|ipa=ˈlɪʔ.fja.vi|src=FE}} phrase, expression (''lì'fya'' language) :{{NaviSE|n|Na'vi|ipa=ˈnaʔ.vi|src=.}} the People (unknown derivation) :{{NaviSE|n|sänumvi|ipa=sæ.ˈnum.vi|src=.}} lesson :{{NaviSE|n|txepvi|tepvi|ipa=ˈtʼɛp.vi|src=FE}} spark (''txep'' fire) :{{NaviSE|n|vurvi|ipa=ˈvuɾ.vi|src=.}} summary, synopsis (''vur'' story)
{{NaviHW|v|v|ir|ä|ipa=vi.ˈɾæ|src=.}} :spread, proliferate
{{NaviHW|n|vitra|ipa=vit.ˈɾa|src=.}} :soul :{{NaviSE|n|Ayvitrayä Ramunong|sn=Ramunog|ipa=ai̯.vit.ˈɾa.jæ ɾa.ˈmu.noŋ|src=?}} the Well of Souls :{{NaviSE|n|Vitrautral|ipa=vit.ˈɾa.ut.ɾal|src=.}} the Tree of Souls
{{NaviHW|num|vol|ipa=ˈvol|src=.}} :eight (octal 10: the base of the numeral system) :{{NaviSE|adj|volve|ipa=ˈvol.vɛ|src=.}} eighth :{{NaviSE|num|volaw|ipa=vo.ˈlau̯|src=.}} nine (octal 11) ::{{NaviSE|adj|volawve|ipa=vo.ˈlau̯.vɛ|src=.}} ninth :{{NaviSE|num|vomun|ipa=vo.ˈmun|src=.}} ten (octal 12) ::{{NaviSE|adj|vomuve|ipa=vo.ˈmu.vɛ|src=.}} tenth :{{NaviSE|num|vopey|ipa=vo.ˈpɛi̯|src=.}} eleven (octal 13) ::{{NaviSE|adj|vopeyve|ipa=vo.ˈpɛi̯.vɛ|src=.}} eleventh :{{NaviSE|num|vosìng|sn=vosìg|ipa=vo.ˈsɪŋ|src=.}} twelve (octal 14) ::{{NaviSE|adj|vosìve|ipa=vo.ˈsɪ.vɛ|src=.}} twelfth :{{NaviSE|num|vomrr|ipa=vo.ˈmr̩|src=.}} thirteen (octal 15) ::{{NaviSE|adj|vomrrve|ipa=vo.ˈmr̩.vɛ|src=.}} thirteenth :{{NaviSE|num|vofu|ipa=vo.ˈfu|src=.}} fourteen (octal 16) ::{{NaviSE|adj|vofuve|ipa=vo.ˈfu.vɛ|src=.}} fourteenth :{{NaviSE|num|vohin|ipa=vo.ˈhin|src=.}} fifteen (octal 17) ::{{NaviSE|adj|vohive|ipa=vo.ˈhi.vɛ|src=.}} fifteenth :{{NaviSE|num|mevol|ipa=ˈmɛ.vol|src=.}} sixteen (octal 20) ::{{NaviSE|adj|mevolve|ipa=ˈmɛ.vol.vɛ|src=.}} sixteenth :{{NaviSE|num|mevolaw|ipa=mɛ.vo.ˈlau̯|src=.}} seventeen (octal 21) ::{{NaviSE|adj|mevolawve|ipa=mɛ.vo.ˈlau̯.vɛ|src=.}} seventeenth :{{NaviSE|num|pxevol|ipa=ˈpʼɛ.vol|src=.}} twenty-four (octal 30) :{{NaviSE|num|tsìvol|sn=cìvol|ipa=ˈtsɪ.vol|src=.}} thirty-two (octal 40) :{{NaviSE|num|mrrvol|ipa=ˈmr̩.vol|src=.}} forty (octal 50) :{{NaviSE|num|puvol|ipa=ˈpu.vol|src=.}} forty-eight (octal 60) :{{NaviSE|num|kivol|ipa=ˈki.vol|src=.}} fifty-six (octal 70) :{{NaviSE|num|vozam|ipa=vo.zam|src=FE}} five-hundred-twelve (octal 1000) [stress?]
{{NaviHW|n|vrrtep|ipa=ˈvr̩.tɛp|src=.}} :demon
{{NaviHW|n|vul|ipa=ˈvul|src=.}} :branch (of a tree)
{{NaviHW|n|vur|ipa=ˈvuɾ|src=.}} :story :{{NaviSE|n|vurvi|ipa=ˈvuɾ.vi|src=.}} summary, synopsis
==W==
{{NaviHW|n|way|ipa=ˈwai̯|src=.}} :song :{{NaviSE|n|waytelem|ipa=ˈwai̯.tɛ.lɛm|src=.}} song cord [sic]
{{NaviHW|adp|wä|-X+|ipa=wæ|src=.}} :against (opposed to)
{{NaviHW|pn|we|ipa=ˈwɛ|src=FE|sa=oe|this=(Pronunciation spelling of}} "I" before a case ending)
{{NaviHW|v|w||em|ipa=ˈwɛm|src=.}} :fight :{{NaviSE|n|wempongu|sn=wempogu|ipa=ˈwɛm.po.ŋu|src=.}} military squad or clan
{{NaviHW|pn|weng, wenga-|ipa=ˈwɛŋ, ˈwɛ.ŋa|src=FE|sa=oeng|this=(Pronunciation spelling of}} "we") [stress?]
{{NaviHW|adj|wew|ipa=ˈwɛu̯|src=.}} :cold :{{NaviSE|phrase|oe 'efu wew|src=FE}} "I am (I feel) cold"
{{NaviHW|v|w||eyn|ipa=ˈwɛi̯n|src=.}} :draw, illustrate
{{NaviHW|adj|win|ipa=ˈwin|src=.}} :fast, quick :{{NaviSE|adv|nìwin|ipa=nɪ.ˈwin|src=.}} fast, quickly :{{NaviSE|vt|win s||i|ipa=ˈwin.si|src=.}} rush, hurry :{{NaviSE|vi|win säp||i|ipa=ˈwin.sæ.ˈpi|src=.}} be in a rush, hurry up
{{NaviHW|intj|wiya!|ipa=ˈwi.ja|src=.}} :oy! whoa! (expression of warning or frustration)
{{NaviHW|v|w|ìntx|u|ipa=wɪn.ˈtʼu|src=.}} :to show :{{NaviSE|v|fyaw|ìntx|u|ipa=ˈfja.wɪn.ˈtʼu|src=.}} to guide (''fya'o'' 'way')<!-- stress from Frommer message --> ::{{NaviSE|n|tìfyawìntxu|ipa=tɪ.ˈfja.wɪn.ˈtʼu|src=.}} guidance
{{NaviHW|suff|wll|-X|ipa=wl̩}} :(suffix in various plant names, from '''ewll'' plant)
{{NaviHW|adj|wok|ipa=ˈwok|src=.}} :loud
{{NaviHW||wong|sn=wog|ipa=ˈwoŋ}} :? :{{NaviSE|adj|kewong|sn=kewog|ipa=ˈkɛ.woŋ|src=.}} alien :{{NaviSE|n|ketuwong|sn=ketuwog|hetuwong|ipa=ˈkɛ.tu.woŋ|src=.}} an alien
{{NaviHW|n|wotx|ipa=ˈwotʼ|src=.}} :whole, totality :{{NaviSE|adv|nìwotx|ipa=nɪ.ˈwotʼ|src=.}} all (of), ''in toto,'' completely ::{{NaviSE|phrase|ayngaru nìwotx|ipa=ai̯.ˈŋa.ɾu.nɪ.ˈwotʼ}} to all of you
{{NaviHW||wrr}} :? :{{NaviSE|n, adv|wrrpa|ipa=ˈwr̩.pa|src=.}} outside (''pa'o'' side) :{{NaviSE|adp|mungwrr|-X-|sn=mugwrr|ipa=muŋ.ˈwr̩|src=.}} except (''munge'' take)
{{NaviHW|n|wutso|sn=wuco|ipa=ˈwu.tso|src=.}} :dinner, a served meal
==Y==
{{NaviHW|suff|y|sa=yä|ipa=j|this=military register of -}} in pronouns :{{NaviSE|pn|ngey|sn=gey|ipa=ˈŋɛi̯|sa=nga|this=gen}} your :{{NaviSE|pn|oey|ipa=ˈwɛi̯|sa=oe|this=gen}} my :{{NaviSE|pn|pey|ipa=ˈpɛi̯|sa=po|this=gen}} his, her, its (animate)
{{NaviHW|n|ya|ipa=ˈja|src=.}} :air :{{NaviSE|n|yayo|ipa=ˈja.jo|src=.}} bird (''ioang'' animal)
{{NaviHW|suff|ya|ipa=ja|src=FE}} :(vocative suffix for collective nouns) :{{NaviSE|phrase|na'viya|ipa=ˈnaʔ.vi.ya|src=}} "People!"
{{NaviHW|adj|yawne|ipa=ˈjau̯.nɛ|src=.}} :beloved ::{{NaviSE|phrase|nga yawne lu oer|ipa=ŋa ˈjau̯.nɛ lu ˈwɛɾ}} I love you<!--"most euphonious" word order in Frommer's opinion--> :{{NaviSE|n|tìyawn|ipa=tɪ.ˈjau̯n|src=.}} love :{{NaviSE|n|yawnetu, yawntu|ipa=ˈjau̯.nɛ.tu, ˈjau̯n.tu|src=.}} beloved, loved one
{{NaviHW||yawr}} :(see ''eyawr'' correct)
{{NaviHW|n|yayo|ipa=ˈja.jo|src=.}} :bird (''ya'' air, ''ioang'' animal)
{{NaviHW|suff|yä|ipa=.jæ}} :{{navi|gen}} case suffix, reduced to −'''ä''' after a consonant and the vowels ''i, u, o.'' Changes vowel of pronouns to ''e.'' Reduces to ''-y'' in pronouns in military register. :{{NaviSE|pn|awngeyä|ipa=au̯.ˈŋɛ.jæ|sa=awnga|this=gen|src=FE}} we :{{NaviSE|pn|feyä|ipa=ˈfɛ.jæ|sa=fo|this=gen|src=FE}} they (animate) :{{NaviSE|pn|ngeyä|sn=geyä|ipa=ˈŋɛ.jæ|sa=nga|this=gen}} you :{{NaviSE|pn|oengeyä|ipa=wɛ.ŋɛ.jæ|sa=oeng|this=gen}} we [confirm] :{{NaviSE|pn|peyä|ipa=ˈpɛ.jæ|sa=po|this=gen|src=FE}} s/he :? {{NaviSE|pn|seyä|ipa=ˈsɛ.jæ|sa=sa|this=gen}} they (inanimate) :{{NaviSE|pn|tseyä|sn=ceyä|ipa=ˈtsɛ.jæ|sa=tsa|this=gen|src=FE}} it (inanimate)
{{NaviHW|v|y||än|ipa=ˈjæn|src=.}} :tie down, fasten (cf. ''yìm'')
{{NaviHW|adv|ye'rìn|ipa=ˈjɛʔ.ɾɪn|src=.}} :soon :{{NaviSE|adv|pxiye'rìn|ipa=pʼi.ˈjɛʔ.ɾɪn|src=.}} immediately, very soon (not as soon as ''pxiswaway'')
{{NaviHW||ye'ung|sn=ye'ug|ipa=jɛ.ʔuŋ}} :? :{{NaviSE|n|keye'ung|sn=keye'ug|ipa=kɛ.ˈjɛ.ʔuŋ|src=.}} insanity ::{{NaviSE|adj|lekye'ung||lekye'ung|sn=lekye'ug|ipa=lɛk.ˈjɛ.ʔuŋ|src=.}} insane, crazy
{{NaviHW|vt|y||em|ipa=ˈjɛm|src=.}} :put, place :{{NaviSE|vt|'awstengy||em|sn='awstegyem|ipa=ʔau̯.stɛŋ.ˈjɛm|src=.}} join :{{NaviSE|n|yemfpay|ipa=jɛm.ˈfpai̯|src=F}} immersion ::{{NaviSE|vt|yemfpay s||i|ipa=ˈjɛm.fpai̯.si|src=F}} dip into liquid, immerse
{{NaviHW|n|yerik|ipa=ˈjɛ.ɾik|src=.}} :[[w:Fictional universe of Avatar#List of fauna|Hexapede]] (a deer-like animal)
{{NaviHW|adj|yey|ipa=ˈjɛi̯|src=.}} :straight
{{NaviHW|v|y||ìm|ipa=ˈjɪm|src=.}} :bind (cf. ''yän'')
{{NaviHW|adj|yol|ipa=ˈjol|src=.}} :short (of time)<!--opposite of SG-->
{{NaviHW|vt|y||om|ipa=ˈjom|src=.}} :eat :{{NaviSE|vb|yomt||ìng|sn=yomtìg|ipa=ˈjom.tɪŋ|src=FE}} feed ::{{NaviSE|phrase|nga na'viru yomtìyìng|ipa=ˈŋa ˈnaʔ.vi.ɾu ˈjom.tɪ.jɪŋ}} you will feed the people :{{NaviSE|n|yomhì'ang|sn= yomhì'ag |ipa=jom.ˈhɪʔ.aŋ|src=FE}} dakteron (sp. plant; ''hì'ang'' bug) :{{NaviSE|n|yomioang|sn=yomioag|ipa=jo.mi.ˈo.aŋ|src=FE}} chalice plant (''ioang'' animal)
{{NaviHW|suff|yu|-X|ipa=ju|}} :-er (one who typically performs an action) :{{NaviSE|n|uniltìranyu|ipa=u.nil.tɪ.ˈɾan.ju|src=.}} dreamwalker :{{NaviSE|n|karyu|haryu|ipa=ˈkaɾ.ju|src=.}} teacher :{{NaviSE|n|ngopyu|sn=gopyu|ipa=ˈŋop.ju|src=.}} creator :? {{NaviSE|n|pizayu|fizayu|ipa=ˈpi.za.ju|src=.}} ancestor :{{NaviSE|n|taronyu|saronyu|ipa=ˈta.ɾon.ju|src=.}} hunter :{{NaviSE|n|täftxuyu|säftxuyu|ipa=tæ.ˈftʼu.ju|src=.}} weaver :{{NaviSE|n|tsamsiyu|samsiyu|ipa=ˈtsam.si.ju|src=.}} warrior
{{NaviHW|vt|y||ur|ipa=ˈjuɾ|src=.}} :wash :{{NaviSE|vi|yäp||ur|ipa=jæ.ˈpuɾ|src=FE}} wash oneself, bathe
==Z==
{{NaviHW|v|z|a'|u|ipa=ˈza.ʔu|src=.}} :come ::{{NaviSE|v|emz|a'|u|ipa=ɛm.ˈza.ʔu|src=.}} to pass (a test for initiation) (''em'' over) ::{{NaviSE|n|zusawkrr|ipa=zu.ˈsau̯.kr̩|src=.}} the future (the coming ''krr'' time) :{{NaviSE|pref|za|ipa=za}} toward the speaker, toward the front ::{{NaviSE|v|za'|är|ìp|ipa=za.ˈʔæ.ɾɪp|src=.}} pull (''’ärìp'' move) ::{{NaviSE|v|zam|ung|e|sn=zamuge|ipa=za.ˈmu.ŋɛ|src=.}} bring (''munge'' take, bring) ::{{NaviSE|n|zapxì|ipa=za.ˈpʼɪ|src=.}} front part (''hapxì'' part)
{{NaviHW|num|zam|ipa=ˈzam|src=.}} :sixty-four (octal 100) :{{NaviSE|adj|zamve|ipa=ˈzam.vɛ}} hundredth :{{NaviSE|num|mezam|ipa=ˈmɛ.zam}} hundred-twenty-eight (octal 200) :{{NaviSE|num|pxezam|ipa=ˈpʼɛ.zam}} hundred-ninety-two (octal 300) :{{NaviSE|num|tsìzam|sn=cìzam|ipa=ˈtsɪ.zam}} two-hundred fifty-six (octal 400) :{{NaviSE|num|mrrzam|ipa=ˈmr̩.zam}} three-hundred twenty (octal 500) :{{NaviSE|num|puzam|ipa=ˈpu.zam}} three-hundred eighty-four (octal 600) :{{NaviSE|num|kizam|ipa=ˈki.zam}} four-hundred forty-eight (octal 700) :{{NaviSE|num|vozam|ipa=vo.zam}} five-hundred-twelve (octal 1000) [stress?] :{{NaviSE|num|zazam|ipa=za.zam}} four-thousand-ninety-six (octal 10,000), myriad [stress?]
{{NaviHW|v|z||awng|sn=zawg|ipa=ˈzau̯ŋ|src=.}} :shriek, scream
{{NaviHW|n|zekwä|ipa=ˈzɛk.wæ|src=.}} :finger :{{NaviSE|n|venzek|ipa=ˈvɛn.zɛk|src=.}} toe (''venu'' foot)
{{NaviHW|v|z|en|e|ipa=ˈzɛ.nɛ|src=.}} :must (modal verb) :{{NaviSE|v|z||enke|ipa=ˈzɛŋ.kɛ|src=.}} must not (pronounced ''zengke'') :{{NaviSE|v|ke zene|ipa=kɛ.ˈzɛ.nɛ|src=FE}} do not need to<!--stress assumed-->
{{NaviHW|v|zengke|ipa=ˈzɛŋ.kɛ|sa=zene|this=(Pronunciation spelling of}} mustn't)
{{NaviHW|v|z|er|ok|ipa=ˈzɛ.ɾok|src=.}} :remember
{{NaviHW|n|zìsìt|ipa=ˈzɪ.sɪt|src=.}} :year :{{NaviSE|phrase|ayzìsìtä kato|ipa=ai̯.ˈzɪ.sɪ.tæ ˈka.to}} rhythm of the years
{{NaviHW|n|zìze'|ipa=zɪ.ˈzɛʔ|src=.}} :hellfire wasp
{{NaviHW|v|z||ong|sn=zog|ipa=ˈzoŋ|src=.}} :save, defend :{{NaviSE|adj|zawnong|sn=zawnog|ipa=zau̯.ˈnoŋ}} defended [stress?] ::{{NaviSE|adv|nìzawnong|sn=nìzawnog|ipa=nɪ.ˈzau̯.noŋ|src=.}} safely [irregular stress] :{{NaviSE|n|zongtseng|sn=zogceg|ipa=ˈzoŋ.tsɛŋ|src=.}} refuge (''tsenge'' place)
{{NaviHW|n|zoplo|ipa=zop.ˈlo|src=.}} :offense, insult
{{NaviHW|v|z||up|ipa=ˈzup|src=.}} :fall; be defeated/overwhelmed :{{NaviSE|v|tungzup|sn=tugzup|ipa=tuŋ.ˈzup|src=.}} drop (''tung'' allow)
{{NaviHW|n|zusawkrr|ipa=zu.ˈsau̯.kr̩|src=.}} the future (''za'u'' come) <noinclude>
{{Na'vi TOC}} </noinclude> {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Kwamikagami moved page [[Na'vi/Na'vi-English dictionary/liquids]] to [[Na'vi/Na'vi–English dictionary/liquids]]
revision.text:
__NOTOC__<noinclude>{{Na'vi TOC}}</noinclude>
==L==
{{NaviHW|suff|l|sa=−ìl|ipa=l|this=Form of {{navi|erg}}}} after a vowel.
{{NaviHW|adj|lahe|ipa=ˈla.hɛ|src=.}} :other ::{{NaviSE||aylaru, aylari|ipa=ai̯.ˈla.ɾu|src=.}} to, regarding the others; short for '''aylaheru, aylaheri''' {{IPA|/ai̯.ˈla.hɛ.ɾu/}} :{{NaviSE|pn|lapo|ipa=ˈla.po|src=.}} another, another one, other one, someone else, something else :{{NaviSE|vi|l|at|em|ipa=ˈla.tɛm|src=.}} change ::{{NaviSE|vt|leyk|at|em|ipa=lɛi̯.ˈka.tɛm|src=FE}} change
{{NaviHW|v|l||am|ipa=ˈlam|src=.}} :seem, appear :{{NaviSE|n|tìlam|sìlam?|ipa=tɪˈlam|src=.}} appearance, look ::{{NaviSE|adv|tatlam|ipa=tat.ˈlam|src=.}} apparently (''ta tìlam'')
{{NaviHW|adj|laro|ipa=ˈla.ɾo|src=.}} :clean
{{NaviHW|v|l|ats|i|sn=laci|ipa=la.ˈtsi|src=.}} :keep up (with someone)
{{NaviHW|adj|law|ipa=ˈlau̯|src=.}} :certain, clear :{{NaviSE|adv|nìlaw|ipa=nɪˈlau̯|src=.}} clearly :{{NaviSE|phrase|law lu ngaru}} it is clear to you / you know
{{NaviHW|adj|layon|ipa=la.ˈjon|src=.}} :black
{{NaviHW|pref|le|X-|ipa=lɛ}} :(adjectivizing prefix: look up by root)
{{NaviHW|v|l||ek|ipa=ˈlɛk|src=.}} :obey, heed
{{NaviHW|v|l||en|ipa=ˈlɛn|src=.}} :happen, occur
{{NaviHW||ler|ipa=ˈlɛɾ}}<!-- back-formation from ''lertu'' --> :? :{{NaviSE|n|lertu|ipa=ˈlɛɾ.tu|src=.}} colleague
{{NaviHW|n|lew|ipa=ˈlɛu̯|src=.}} :cover, lid :{{NaviSE|v|lew s||i|ipa=ˈlɛu̯ si|src=.}} to cover
{{NaviHW|suff|lie|-X|ipa=ˈli.ɛ}} :(found in:) :{{NaviSE|adv|'awlie|ipa=ʔau̯.ˈli.ɛ|src=.}} once (in the past)
{{NaviHW||lì'|ipa=lɪʔ}} :? :{{NaviSE|n|lì'u|ipa=ˈlɪ.ʔu|src=.}} word ("spoken thing") ::{{NaviSE|n|kemlì'u|hemlì'u|ipa=ˈkɛm.lɪ.ʔu|src=.}} verb ::{{NaviSE|n|tstxolì'u|stxolì'u|sn=ctxolì'u|ipa=ˈtstʼo.lɪ.ʔu|src=.}} noun :{{NaviSE|n|lì'fya|ipa=ˈlɪʔ.fja|src=.}} language ("way of speaking") ::{{NaviSE|phrase|lì'fya leNa'vi|ipa=ˈlɪʔ.fja lɛ.ˈnaʔ.vi}} the Na'vi language ::{{NaviSE|n|lì'fyavi|ipa=ˈlɪʔ.fja.vi|src=FE}} phrase, expression
{{NaviHW|vi|l||ìm|ipa=ˈlɪm|src=.}} :be far :{{NaviSE|adv|alìm|ipa=a.ˈlɪm|src=.}} far away, at a distance [no ''*lìma'']
{{NaviHW|suff|lo|ipa=lo|sa=alo|src=F}} turn, number of times :{{NaviSE|adv|'awlo|ipa=ˈʔau̯.lo|src=FE}} once :{{NaviSE|adv|melo|ipa=ˈmɛ.lo|src=FE}} twice
{{NaviHW|n|Loak|ipa=ˈlo.ak|src=FE}} :(male name)
{{NaviHW|v|l||ok|ipa=ˈlok|src=.}} :approach, draw near :{{NaviSE|adp|lok|-X-|ipa=lok|src=.}} close to
{{NaviHW|vt|l|on|u|ipa=lo.ˈnu|src=.}} :let go, release
{{NaviHW|adj|lor|ipa=ˈloɾ|src=.}} :pleasant to the senses or mind: beautiful (object, sound, smell, use of language), delicious (food), etc. :{{NaviSE|n|nìlor|ipa=nɪ.ˈloɾ|src=FE}} beautifully :{{NaviSE|n|tìlor|ipa=tɪ.ˈloɾ|src=.}} beauty :{{NaviSE|n|loreyu|ipa=lo.ˈɾɛ.ju|src=FE}} [[w:Fictional universe of Avatar|helicoradian]] (carnivorous plant; ''ìreyu'' spiral)
{{NaviHW|n|lrrtok|ipa=ˈlr̩.tok|src=.}} :a smile; (pl) blessings (of Eywa), happy (as for a celebration) :{{NaviSE|v|lrrtok s||i|ipa=ˈlr̩.tok.si|src=?}} to smile (dative = upon); to bless (of Eywa)
{{NaviHW|vi|l||u|ipa=ˈlu|src=.}} :be (am, is, are, was, were) :{{NaviSE|vb|lu|src=FE}} have :{{NaviSE|adp|luke|-X-|ipa=ˈlu.kɛ|src=.}} without (''ke'' not)
{{NaviHW|n|lun|ipa=ˈlun|src=.}} :reason :{{NaviSE|adv|lumpe|ipa=ˈlum.pɛ|src=.}} why? (= ''pelun'') :{{NaviSE|adv|pelun|ipa=pɛ.ˈlun|src=.}} why? (= ''lumpe'') :{{NaviSE|conj|taluna, talun|ipa=ta.ˈlu.na, ta.ˈlun|src=.}} because (with English clause order) :{{NaviSE|conj|alunta|ipa=a.ˈlun.ta|src=FE}} because (with opposite clause order)
==R==
{{NaviHW|suff|r|sa=−ru|ipa=ɾ|this=Short form of {{navi|dat}}}}

revision.text:
==MAM Contributions== I researched the topic and made the following additions:
Link to the NRP Reading Summary in section "Freereading.net"
Added YouTube videos in section "User guides..."
Added new section "what does open source mean" (with links)
Cleaned up a few typos in various sections
My contributions also show up in the history under the IP address 66.37.54.251 as well as my name. --[[User:Margaret.mourer|Margaret.mourer]] ([[User talk:Margaret.mourer|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Margaret.mourer|contribs]]) 17:19, 5 March 2011 (UTC)
A lot of information on Free Reading! You did great with your new section, written in NPOV and very succint. The rest of the page could use a bit of organization though, couldn't it? Some of the content seems out of sequence; I wouldn't feel confident moving paragraphs around in a more logical manner and I'm sure you didn't have time or inclination either! But your contributions are wonderful. Louise[[User:L0u1ser1ce|L0u1ser1ce]] ([[User talk:L0u1ser1ce|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/L0u1ser1ce|contribs]]) 21:07, 6 March 2011 (UTC)
I researched the topic, typed the content, and tried editing to make the page look professional. ss
I proof read the article, making corrections where necessary. I also found and inserted several pictures. mf
I believe the references are fixed, and I added a link for the video tutorials. I am not sure about the text boxes but I shortened the sentences. They look good to me. I adjusted the pictures, making the classroom one bigger so it makes more sense under the classroom uses paragraph. If you can think of anything else let me know. mf
I think I was looking at the page previous and not the one after. I hope the references are now correct. Please let us know. I made the picture small again. :)
m & s: # The references are not quite in the format of the example page. You can also check the pages before yours in our own wikibook. (out of time! --[[Special:Contributions/72.81.93.55|72.81.93.55]] ([[User talk:72.81.93.55|talk]]) 17:57, 15 March 2010 (UTC)) --[[User:Sgarrigan|Sgarrigan]] ([[User talk:Sgarrigan|talk]]) 05:08, 9 March 2010 (UTC)
'''Four items to think about''' (in priority order) # Your references should follow the model I presented in the example page at http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Talk:Assistive_Technology_in_Education. The page before yours uses this model, too, so you can see how it was done. # All topics are at the same level of heading. If that's what you want, it's OK. If you want headings and sub-headings, see the sample page or the previous one. # The photos have captions that say "caption." Is that what you wanted? # The photos seems to overlap the text in a gray text box. Is there a reason for the text box? Just putting the text in as a normal paragraph may allow the photo to adjust itself better. The example page is a model to follow for all of the three items above (if you have time). --[[User:Sgarrigan|Sgarrigan]] ([[User talk:Sgarrigan|talk]]) 04:19, 8 March 2010 (UTC)
== Oct. 2010 update ==
I updated this page... add/update pics - uploaded one picture I found on everystockphoto.com. Selected two other photos from wikimedia. Set the horizontal alignment to left for one photo. Uses in classroom section has a random link at the end of #5 add a description of freereading as the first section add a link to the pdf that shows how freereading correlates to the Florida standards removed what is open source section - and just added a link in the first section to wikipedia description of opensource more detailed description of the program add a list of program resources add what the program does not cover rearranged some of the information
LB [[User:Bergerl|Bergerl]] ([[User talk:Bergerl|talk]]) 18:26, 2 October 2010 (UTC)
Great job LB this site seems very useful. Being an elementary teacher I could find many uses for this sit. Thanks. AF
== Open source ==
"Open source" does ''not'' mean that the materials are free in terms of cost. It only refers to the fact that the materials are open for modification and redistribution by users. It's the well-worn distinction between "free as in speech" and "free as in beer". --[[User:Fishpi|Fishpi]] ([[User talk:Fishpi|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Fishpi|contribs]]) 16:48, 3 March 2011 (UTC) Thanks for making that distinction. [[User:Margaret.mourer|Margaret.mourer]] ([[User talk:Margaret.mourer|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Margaret.mourer|contribs]]) 17:14, 5 March 2011 (UTC)mam
== MTP Additions ==
In working on the Wikibook page I did the following:
Researched the topics on the page and added several notations that linked to the material talked about that previously had no citations MTP
Additionally, I added the following sections and content within the sections i.e. Freereading and the Open Educational Movement, Advantages to the Program, Updates the Florida Program (Partnership with Science Foundation) MTP
Also, I proofread the pages and made several spelling corrections in addition I cleaned up the wording in several sections and listed the board of the organization. I also update the section on its use in Florida MTP
[[User:Mthomasphillips|Mthomasphillips]] ([[User talk:Mthomasphillips|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Mthomasphillips|contribs]]) 20:13, 4 March 2011 (UTC)
==March 2011 Comments ==
Mthomasphillips and M - nice job on how the page is set up as well as the thorough information that you have included. I appreciated the new categories that you developed. LH
M & M—Nice job on the updates that you made to the page on FreeReading. Though this was a topic that we researched in class, I sure learned a lot! Seeing the specifics of the actual program was very helpful. It made me realize that the program does have some resources like the decodable passages and irregular word cards to name a few that I can use for my 5th grade students. It is also helpful to see that there are resources out there to help me understand the process if I have difficulties. ---N.K. 2011
Julie's comments - I found this page to be very informative. Great resources and references worth exploring.

[[User:Joseph.Straw|Joseph.Straw]] ([[User talk:Joseph.Straw|talk]]) 01:19, 9 October 2010 (UTC)
Nice job JS. A lot of the information on this page is very interesting. It seems like whether you like it or not user - generated content will be in every classroom before you no it. AF
JH and SW edited the document and added information, including references, as indicated within the document. The purpose of the changes was to update the site based on current research.

==Introduction== Prescriptions for mediation are used in febrile diseases of the ''shaoyang'' meridian, ''disharmony'' between the liver and the spleen, as well diseases that arise from the intermingling of ''cold and heat''.
==Types of Formulas==
*[[../Prescriptions for Treating Shaoyang Disease by Mediation/]] *[[../Prescriptions for Regulating the Liver and Spleen/]] *[[../Prescriptions for Harmonising cold-heat Syndrome/]] *[[../Prescriptions for Expelling both Exterior and Interior Pathogenic Factors/]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Chinese Medicinal Formulas/Prescriptions for Treating Shaoyang Disease by Mediation

revision.text:
==Introduction== Shaoyang diseases are febrile diseases that affect the shaoyang meridian. It includes the common cold, influenza, chronic hepatitis, acute or chronic cholecystitis, pleuritis, pyelonephritis, postpartum infection and gastric ulcer.
==Prescriptions==
*[[../Xiao Chaihu Tang/]] *[[../Haoqin Qingdan Tang/]]
{{BookCat}}

'''Scientifica''' is a collection of pedagogical articles outlining the ''epistemic foundations'' of modern scientific research as an aid to new and current researchers, especially graduate students. For each topic, which is to be kept as restricted as possible in scope, the Scientifica article will answer the following questions: : In what regime and under what conditions do we believe the current scientific theory to be applicable? : What experimental or theoretical evidence leads us to believe the theory to be (approximately) true? : What research avenues exist for improving the beauty, applicability, and/or accuracy of the theory? : What experimental or theoretical evidence restricts alternative avenues of inquiry? The Scientifica article covering a certain topic will generally assume familiarity with the basics of that topic. For example, rather than teaching one how to solve certain problems in general relativity (GR) ''given'' the mathematical postulates of GR (i.e. equivalence principle, locally obeys special relativity, etc.), the relevant Scientifica article will examine the experimental evidence supporting these postulates, as well as the motivations for and problems with alternative approaches (e.g. modified Newtonian Dynamics).
An historical approach is often helpful for introducing the logical structure of ideas, but Scientifica is not a mere ''history'' of a research field. For instance, modern experiments which more accurately demonstrate the non-existence of the luminiferous aether are more epistemically compelling than the original Michelson–Morley experiment.
Finally, Scientifica covers more than just extremely well established theories like GR, although it is definitively ''not'' a platform for original research. It catalogs both research programs, like tensor-scalar cosmology, and foundational ideas, like the holographic principle. The goal is to get new researchers up to speed on the "lore" of their subject as quickly as possible. Further, Scientifica articles serve as a guide to the literature. References to original publications and review articles are crucial.
==Articles==
[[/Black Hole Thermodynamics/]]
{{Subjects|Science}} {{Alphabetical|S}} {{status|0%}}

==Introduction== This formula was first published in [[w:Shanghan lun|Shanghan Lun]] (Treatise on Exogenous Febrile Diseases). Its Chinese name means "Minor Decoction of Bupleurum". This formula is typically decocted in water for oral application.
==Ingredients==
The ingredients of Xiao Chaihu Tang are: # Chaihu - 24g, # Huangqin - 9g, # Renshen - 9g, # Zhigancao - 6g, # Banxia - 9g, # Shengjiang - 9g, # Dazao - 4 pieces.
The main herb is Chaihu which expels the pathogenic factors in the shaoyang meridian. The secondary herb is Huangqin which purges accumulated ''heat''. Renshen, Zhigancao and Dazao supplement ''[[w:qi|Qi]]'' and strengthen body resistance. Banxia and Shenjiang regulate the stomach and prevent vomiting. Zhigancao coordinates the actions of various herbs in the formula.
==Application== This formula has been used for attacks of chills and fever, fullness of the chest, influenza, the common cold, chronic hepatitis, acute or chronic cholecystitis, pleuristis, pyelonephritis, postpartum infection, gastric ulcer and other febrile diseases of the shaoyang meridian.
{{BookCat}}

Black Hole Thermodynamics is a potentially very important subject for developing a theory of quantum gravity. In short, is a set of principles which extend thermodynamic concepts and laws, which appear to fail when applied to black holes at first glace, into the realm of general relativity.
==Logical Foundations==
===Recall basic thermo logic=== (1) We observe conservation of energy in non-dissipative systems after we define (i) potential/internal energy and (ii) work/kinetic energy: dU = dW
(2) We observe that work can be converted completely into "hotness" (something proportional to heat) at a constant exchange rate in dissipative systems. This suggest we define heat (in units of energy) such that for single material, :dU = dQ + dW.
(3) For a single material which is not a heat engine, dU=dQ+dW is almost a tautology. However, by allowing multiple materials with different heat capacities interact, dU=dQ+dW is non-trivial.
(4) Thermodynamically, we get the second law by starting with Lord Kelvin's postulate (can't turn heat purely into energy) or Clausius' postulate (heat flows from hot to cold) and showing that the quantity dS =dQ/T cannot decrease.
(4') Statistical-mechanically, we get the second law by counting states, assuming the fundamental assumption, and showing that S *almost* always increases.
===Surface Gravity-Temperature Analogy=== It can be derived based on the laws of classical GR that the surface gravity, k, is constant everywhere along the horizon of a *stationary* BH (Schwarzchild, Kerr, whatever). At first, this is not very interesting because many quantities (e.g. curvature, radius) are constant along the horizon of a BH due to the high symmetry of stationary BHs in 4 dimensions. However, in higher dimensions BHs can be much more complicated, so that things like curvature and radius are not constant along the horizon. Nevertheless, the surface gravity is *always* constant in arbitrary dimensions once the BH has settled down.
'''This weakly suggests that the surface gravity is a monotonic function of the temperature T ( :=dQ/dS ) in the true theory of quantum gravity.'''
===Area-Entropy Analogy=== It can be derived based on the laws of classical GR that, in a system with one or more BHs, the sum of the horizon areas never decreases. Note that the total mass is *not* conserved. In general, some energy will be radiated away in the form of gravity waves, so the final mass of a BH created by merging other BHs together can be less than the initial total mass.
'''This moderately suggests that the BH area A is proportional to the entropy S ( := ln g) in the true theory of quantum gravity.'''1 (Applied to a single BH, we would only have monotonicity. But since we can add BH's together, we get proportionality.)
===Hawking Radiation=== If you drive a motorized wheelchair, you can derive based on QFT in curved space that stationary BH's radiate like black bodies with temperature T = k/2*pi . This holds true even though the relationship between T and other BH parameters (q, M, J) is different for different types of BHs. Apparently, it's a pretty convincing derivation, although see [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawking_radiation#Trans-Planckian_problem] and references therein for objections.
'''This strongly suggests that the surface gravity and the temperature of a BH are related by''' :T = k/2*pi '''in the true theory of quantum gravity.'''
===Conservation of Energy Analogy=== It can be derived based on the laws of classical GR that :dM = k dA / 8pi + w dJ + Vdq, where :J=ang momentum added to BH, :w=ang velocity of BH, :V=external electric potential, :q=charge added to BH. This is analogous to dU=dQ+dW. The identifications are :dU --> dM , :dW --> w dJ + V dq , :dQ --> k dA / 2pi . The first two are not just analogies; in relativity, the mass of a system at rest ''is'' its energy, and wdJ+Vdq is precisely the work done on system, BH or no BH.
'''This moderately suggests that the''' ::k dA / 2pi = dQ = T dS '''which supports our suspicion that k and A are functions of T and S, respectively. Given the Hawking radiation relation, T = k/2*pi, we get''' ::S = A/4 '''in the true theory of quantum gravity.'''
===A bit more evidence=== (1) Work cannot be extracted from isolated BH's, but work can be extracted by bringing two BH's together. (= Work cannot be extracted from isolated systems in thermo equilibrium, but but work can be extracted by bringing two systems in equilibrium together.) The analogy is imperfect because work can be extracted by combining two BH's at same temp, but usually one can't extract work from two systems at same temp. This imperfection may just be due to the fact that there is potential energy between separated BHs, but not between textbook thermo systems.
(2) The proportionality constant between A and S was estimated by Bekenstein before the discovery of Hawking radiation fixed it exactly. Basically, he considered assigning a minimum of one bit of entropy to an isolated particle and seeing how much area was added to a BH if you dropped the particle in from a distance of one Compton wavelength above the horizon. He argued that you couldn't have dropped it from any closer to the horizon (thereby reducing arbitrarily the energy--i.e. area--added to the BH for the given amount of entropy) because of the finite-width of the wavepacket. This is independent support (within an order of magnitude) for S=A/4.
==Summary of the Historial Literature==
'''J. D. Bekenstein, "Black Holes and Entropy", Phys. Rev. D 7, 2333 (1972)''' [http://prd.aps.org/abstract/PRD/v7/i8/p2333_1] :Bekenstein points out analogies between BH's and thermo: ::(1) BH surface area (which is proportional to the "irreducible mass") never decreases. [ = Entropy never decreases] ::(2) No energy may be extracted from an isolated Schwarzchild BH, but two SBH's may be brought together to release energy (through grav. radiation), but the final composite BH must have an irreducible mass at least as large as the orginal system (M_irr^2 = M_1^2 + M_2^2). [ = No energy can be extracted from an isolated system in equilibrium at some temperature, but energy can be extracted by bringing two systems of different temperature together] ::(3) there is a BH analog of dE = TdS - PdV ::(4) more, but I haven't finished reading
'''S.W. Hawking, "Particle creation by black holes", Communications in Mathematical Physics 43, 199 (1975)''' [http://www.springerlink.com/content/c4553033029k5wk6/] :Hawking discovers Hawing radiation and derives a temperature for the BH of a given mass. This gives the exact proportionality constant between surface area and entropy. (I haven't read this yet.)
'''J. D. Bekenstein, "Universal upper bound on the entropy-to-energy ratio for bounded systems", Phys. Rev. D 23, 287 (1980)''' [http://prd.aps.org/abstract/PRD/v23/i2/p287_1] :Bekenstein uses BH's to establish upper bound on entropy.
'''R. D. Sorkin, "Toward a Proof of Entropy Increase in the Presence of Quantum Black Holes", Phys. Rev. Lett. 56, 1885 (1986)''' [http://prl.aps.org/abstract/PRL/v56/i18/p1885_1] :Sorkin makes stronger argument that second law of thermo is preserved with quantum BH's. (I haven't read this yet; it was mentioned in Bekenstein's popular article in Scientific American).
'''G. 't Hooft, "Dimensional Reduction in Quantum Gravity", arXiv:gr-qc/9310026 (1993)''' [http://arxiv.org/abs/gr-qc/9310026] :'t Hooft argues that the correct theory of QG should have degrees of freedom that scale with the area, not the volume. I think this scaling feature is the precise way to state the holographic principle, not bs like "the universe really exists as a hologram on a far away surface" (as if that surface existed somewhere in a 3D space). Bekenstein himself states the holographic principle as "[the correct theory of QC] defined only on the 2-D boundary of [a] region completely describes the 3-D physics". I assume he means that the fundamental 2-surface (which exista a priori to the 3-surface of our experience) has the same topology as the boundary of the 3-surface of our experience.
'''L. Susskind, "The World as a Hologram", J. Math. Phys. 36, 6377 (1995)''' [http://link.aip.org/link/?JMAPAQ/36/6377/1] Susskind connects this to string theory. Although I don't think you or I care much about the implications for string theory, this is considered an important paper, and I think it had some good discussion at the beginning independent of strings.
==Review Articles==
'''R. Busso, "The holographic principle", Rev. Mod. Phys. 74, 825 (2002)''' [http://rmp.aps.org/abstract/RMP/v74/i3/p825_1]
{{BookCat}}

The '''Oracle Database''' (also referred as '''Oracle RDBMS''' or '''Oracle''') consists of a relational database management system (RDBMS) produced and marketed by Oracle Corporation. Oracle had become a major presence in database computing.
== Table of Contents == * [[/Introduction/]] * [[/Installing/]] * [[/Creating a Database/]] * [[/Database Interfaces/]] * [[/Controlling/]] * [[/Storage Structures/]] * [[/Administering Users/]] * [[/Managing Schema Objects/]] * [[/Managing Data/]] * [[/SQL/]] See also: [[Oracle Programming]] * [[/PL/SQL/]] * [[/Security/]] * [[/Net Services/]] * [[/Shared Servers/]] * [[/Performance Monitoring/]] * [[/Proactive Maintenance/]] * [[/Undo Management/]] * [[/Monitoring and Resolving Lock Conflicts/]] * [[/Backup and Recovery Concepts/]] * [[/Backups/]] * [[/Recovery/]]
== Oracle Database Management Tools== * [http://www.oracle.com/technology/products/database/sql_developer/index.html Oracle SQL Developer] * [http://oracle.navicat.com Navicat for Oracle GUI Admin Tool]
== External links == * [http://www.oracle.com/technology/software/products/database/oracle10g/ Oracle Database], a view provided by Oracle Corporation * [http://www.scribd.com/doc/3158842/Oracle-10g-Database-Administration-Concepts-Implementation-Made-Simple- Oracle tutorial], a quick understanding and visualization of Oracle environment and administration * [http://www.oraclepassport.com Oracle PL/SQL], an easy guide to learn Oracle PL/SQL. Also most of the Oracle Topics discussed.
